title: Money
summary: Essential vocabulary to talk about money, including common nouns, verbs, and verb phrases related to spending, payments, savings, and more.

sections.heading: Verbs and Verb Phrases Used to Talk About Money
sections.content: This section covers common verbs and phrases used when talking about money management.

examples.definition: To use money to pay for something.
examples.example: I spent $20 on petrol yesterday.

examples.definition: To spend money on things that you don’t need.
examples.example: John wasted all his money on that sports car.

examples.definition: To ask for and take someone else’s money with the intention of returning it.
examples.example: I borrowed $200 from my sister. I’ll pay her back when I get paid.

examples.definition: To give money to someone on the condition that they return it.
examples.example: My sister lent me $200. I’ll pay her back when I get paid.

examples.definition: To give money to a seller in exchange for products or services.
examples.example: Tom paid for the taxi.

examples.definition: To return money that you have borrowed.
examples.example: I need to pay Joe back the money I borrowed from him last week.

examples.definition: To require a particular amount of money in exchange for something.
examples.example: The ring costs €299.

examples.definition: To ask for money in exchange for goods or services.
examples.example: The mechanic charged me €50 for fixing my car.

examples.definition: To not use or waste money, or gradually collect money by spending less than what is earned.
examples.example: I saved a lot of money by booking my tickets online.

examples.definition: To have enough money to pay for something.
examples.example: I can afford to buy a new phone because I just got paid.

examples.definition: To be valued at a particular amount of money.
examples.example: The ring is worth over $3,000.

examples.definition: To take money out of an account.
examples.example: I withdrew money from the cash machine.

sections.heading: Nouns Used to Talk About Money
sections.content: This section covers common nouns related to money, such as cash, bank accounts, and expenses.

examples.definition: Money in the form of coins or notes.
examples.example: I paid for the book in cash.

examples.definition: Flat round pieces of metal used as money.
examples.example: I paid for the book with a €5 note and some coins.

examples.definition: Pieces of paper of different values used as money.
examples.example: I paid for the book with a €5 note and some coins.

examples.definition: An arrangement with a bank to look after a customer’s money.
examples.example: I withdrew €50 from my bank account.

examples.definition: Money put into a bank account.
examples.example: To open an account, you need to make a minimum deposit of $500.

examples.definition: A small case for holding notes and coins, often used to carry money.
examples.example: Although there isn’t any cash in my wallet, there are a few credit cards.

examples.definition: A small personalized plastic card used to pay for things.
examples.example: Although there isn’t any cash in my wallet, there are a few credit cards.

examples.definition: A machine where you can withdraw money from your bank account.
examples.example: I withdrew €40 from the ATM.

examples.definition: A piece of paper from the bank that specifies an amount of money to be paid to someone.
examples.example: I paid for the delivery by cheque.

examples.definition: Money lent to you by a bank that you promise to repay with interest.
examples.example: I took out a loan to buy a new car.

examples.definition: A special loan for buying a house or property.
examples.example: We wanted to buy a flat, so we took out a mortgage.

examples.definition: A fixed amount of money given regularly by an employer.
examples.example: Fred’s salary is just under €20,000 a year.

examples.definition: The total money a person earns in a specific time.
examples.example: Sally’s total annual income is just over €45,000.

examples.definition: The money required to do or pay for something.
examples.example: We spend a lot of money on electric bills.

examples.definition: The amount of money available to spend on something.
examples.example: Our holiday budget is €2000; this should cover meals and other expenses.

examples.definition: A communication informing you of how much money you need to pay for goods or services.
examples.example: We spend a lot of money on electric bills.
